I love a book that educates me in a non-painful way. Jahren alternates chapters between her journey as a scientist and her knowledge and passion for botany. Of special interest to me was reading about the difficulties she faced especially as a Research Botanist. Some readers in my book club found her whiny, but I thought she was just being honest in her struggles with an antiseptic upbringing, mental illness, and sexist road blocks from being a woman in a male dominated fields. I learned it takes a really special person to do research experiments.The tension to me of mind numbing monotonous tasks coupled with the stringent standards of proof, well let's just say it's not a field for most people. Added to that is the constant struggle for adequate funding. I found it quite enjoyable with bonus botanic bits.

I bought this book because it was a good deal, wondering if I would ever read it. What a surprise! It is a great combination of life and science. I found it very interesting and will never look at trees or plants in the same way.
I might never look at a trees and plants the same way. Seriously thinking about planting my own oak tree on the back yard and watch it grow.

3 1/2 starsI have always had a love of medicine and science (all though my high school results on science may tell another story) so I was immediately drawn to this book.Hope grew up in her father‚Äôs laboratory surrounded by Bunsen burners, petri dishes and access to everything a curious child my want to investigate in a lab. It‚Äôs not surprising that she was brought up in an academically focused household and even her mother studied part time and included her daughter in her learning process.I really appreciated the fact that all the experiments or processes in the book was explained so that any person no matter how unenlightened about science, could grasp the concepts.‚ÄùMy laboratory is like a church because it is where I figure out what I believe‚ÄùI loved reading about her part-time work at a local hospital while studying ‚Äì it gave me glimpses of the nuts and bolts of running a hospital and more than once I wished that she had become a doctor rather than a botanist.My feelings towards flora is neither here nor there so naturally some of the chapters dealing with the workings of plants didn‚Äôt really interest me but one thing came across crystal clear and that is her absolute passion about what she does for a living.  ‚ÄúI will never stop being ravenously hungry for science, no matter how well it feeds me‚ÄùI also found the sections dealing with just how difficult it is to secure funding for scientific projects are as well as glimpses on Hope dealing with her bi-polar disease, eye-opening. But it‚Äôs her friendship with Bill, her lab partner, that stood out for me. So this is a mix between work as a scientist, information about botany and a young woman trying to carve a foothold for herself in a male dominated industry. This may not be for everyone but it was a very enjoyable and informative read for me.
Enjoyable and really interesting. Loved all the science!

I'm very curious what other scientists, particularly women, think of this book. To me, the best writing in the book was in the short chapters about plants, even though some of the cool plant insights were already familiar to me since I've worked in plant labs for some years. The rest was uneven, tended toward telling instead of showing, and I think because of this the relationships come out feeling flat, even her relationship with Bill which is clearly important and meant to feel more three-dimensional. Overall, although I certainly support women in science telling their stories, this didn't live up to my expectations, not even close, and I would take Evelyn Fox Keller's 'A Feeling for the Organism' or Susan Brind Morrow's 'Wolves and Honey' or Lauren Redniss's 'Radioactive' over Lab Girl any day of the week. One more note: Jahren sometimes explicitly or implicitly gives the impression that there's one correct way to be a scientist: you have to be immediately driven forward by your failures, never discouraged by them, you have to be able to work for 48 hours straight, you have to have always known science is what you wanted. There is no one way to be a scientist: this is completely untrue, as it is untrue of any profession, and don't let it discourage you or any young girl you know from pursuing science.

Such a short book, but it took me forever to read it. I should have liked it more than I actually did. Hope Jahren's part-memoir, part-scientific reflection has humour, memorable personalities, fun educational material, and some truly moving recollections. The problem was that sometimes Jahren's could become too dramatic. I had the misfortune to listen to the audiobook while walking my dog, and I swear it made me want to pull my hair out. The teary, choking voice at the end of nearly every chapter that was supposed to make me feel emotions while the author dwelled in self-pity was like nails on chalkboard. I also went into the book thinking this would be more of a love letter to botany and some interesting findings the author discovered during her career (I never read blurbs), but instead I got mostly a memoir, interlaced some musings on plants that supported the mood for these memories. And this is officially the longest sentence I've ever written. Needless to say, I am sort of underwhelmed. If you are going to read Lab Girl, please avoid the audio, and be prepared for a lifetime worth of over-reactions to ordinary events.

When you write your own memoirs, you can write anything you want - it's your life, or your own stories of your own life. So I can't really fault Hope for telling her story. But I can caution potential readers: if you want to know what's it is like to be a scientist, don't rely on this book. This is just one story, and it is not at all typical. You don't have to work 80 hours per week to be a scientist. You can have a life AND be a scientist. If you're a student, you can find a grad advisor who cares about you and invests in your success and doesn't haze you when you first join the lab. In short, Future Scientists, don't be discouraged by reading this. Science takes all kinds, and life in science can be what you want it to be.

I like to read non-fiction books as a change of pace from my reading fiction titles. My wife's reading group selected Lab Girl, so I gave it a read, too. Hope is a "tree scientist," and she brings a deep passion to her work. I learned all types of new stuff about trees and plants. I like how she writes about her personal life, including her career in academia. Great read.

5 Heartfelt Stars: Achingly beautiful and illuminating "Descending into and then surfacing from winter formed the driving rhythm of our lives."Beautifully written, this books blends together a perfect cadence of science and memoir. Rhythm and cycles permeate the narrative, bouncing between Hope Jahren's ups and downs as a career scientist, and the intricate lives of vegetation. I hadn't even read a synopsis before before I began, and was pleasantly surprised by the delicate unfolding of the book ‚Ä¶ made from paper, derived from intelligent trees ‚Ä¶ ~ Just Trust Me: In Praise Of Strange Books (All 3 are 5 star reads!)~Hope Jahren is a celebrated geochemist and geobiologist, not to mention an exceptionally interesting human being. Currently she works at the University of Oslo, and this book is her origin story.Jahren worked with her mother in the garden growing up, first sparking her love of growing things.‚ÄúBy the end of June the whole crop was well on its way and the world around us was so green that it seemed impossible that it could ever have been otherwise. By July, the sweating leaves of all these plants had pumped the air so full of moisture that the humidity caused the electrical lines to buzz and crackle overhead.‚Äù She also played in her father‚Äôs lab from a young age, inspiring her love for science and hunger to know how things work.‚ÄúThere I transformed from a girl into a scientist, just like Peter Parker becoming Spider-Man, only kind of backward.‚Äù Eventually, Jahren‚Äôs life intersects with a man named Bill, in a lab‚Äîwhere else? He becomes her loyal assistant, moving locations and building labs with her. There was one point where I kind of hoped they‚Äôd get together, but their relationship is unique and special‚Äîmore like best friends or brother and sister.Did I mention the writing is beautiful? Jahren deals with mental illness and loneliness in such a heartfelt manner it‚Äôs impossible not to empathize alongside her. She reads the audiobook and you can hear the emotion in her voice, bleeding through the words. The tone remains positive and manages not to be depressing even when dealing with tough topics. There is hope, and the beauty of science unveiling new understanding to the world. The history and lives of trees are presented in a fascinating way, paralleling various aspects of human lives.If you enjoy plants and true tails of scientific superstars ‚Äî this book is for you.Quotes:‚ÄúShe set her hair in curlers while listening to records of Carl Sandburg‚Äôs poems over and over, and instructed me on how to hear the words differently each time. After discovering Susan Sontag, she explained to me that even meaning itself is a constructed concept, and I learned how to nod and pretend to understand.‚Äù ‚ÄúFull-blown mania lets you see the other side of death. Its onset is profoundly visceral and unexpected, no matter how many times you‚Äôve been through it. It is your body that first senses the urgency of a new world about to bloom. Your vertebrae seem to detach from one another and you elongate as if toward the sun‚Äôs light. You can‚Äôt hear above the sloshing roar of blood pushed through your head by some impossibly sustained orgasm within your beating heart. For the next twenty-four, forty-eight, seventy-two hours you will have to yell to hear yourself over this whooshing. Nothing, nothing can be loud enough or bright enough or move fast enough. The world appears as if through a fish-eye lens; your view is fuzzy with sparkling edges. You have received a grand, systemic injection of Novocain and your entire body tingles briefly before it becomes flaccidly foreign and unreal. Your raised arms are the fleshy petals of a magnificent lily bursting into flower. It deeply dawns on you that this new world about to bloom is you.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere at the end of the world, he danced in the broad and endless daylight, and I accepted him for what he was, instead of what he wished he could be. The potency of my acceptance made me wonder, just a little, if I could turn it inward and accept myself.‚Äù

This memoir could be subtitled ‚ÄúThe Private Lives of Plants,‚Äù because paleobiologist Hope Jahren can‚Äôt help but wax poetic at times about her chosen field of study, with which she is clearly enraptured. Fortunately, she‚Äôs pretty convincing. Since my tastes run more toward gossipy tell-alls than science texts, my favorite parts of Lab Girl were Jahren's personal stories of her romance with her husband and decidedly unromantic relationship with her (occasionally homeless but forever loyal) research partner Bill. Amazingly enough, though, I didn't glaze over during the parts about trees and mosses. Jahren is one of those rare scientists able to express her enthusiasm for her subject in a way that translates to the average Jane. The audio version is read by Jahren herself, which makes the more emotional parts of the book ring with authenticity, but if you're bothered by soft, whispery voices, you might prefer to pick up this one in print. If you close your eyes, Jahren sounds just like Ana Gasteyer's character from the classic SNL sketch ‚ÄúSchweddy Balls.‚ÄùMore book recommendations by me at www.readingwithhippos.com

The name of this book never worked for me - it didn't seem to capture what the book was about, and it is diminuitive in nature. Jahren is not a "girl", and this book is not cutesy, as the title, and even the cover art, would lead you to believe. Jahren's work in geobotany is fascinating, and I really enjoyed the interspersed chapters on plants, trees, natural history. The personal memoir sections were okay - they showed devotion and commitment to the science. I was frustrated with the roadblocks and glass ceilings that Jahren hit/endured as a female scientist, but I was also grew frustrated with Jahren for her continuous lack of foresight and planning, and the ways her actions (and inactions) impacted those around her. I know these symptoms are directly tied to her mental illness, and she writes about that with candor and bravery, and I do agree that we need more of this - normalizing, familiarizing. Thankfully, with time and experience, things did get better - for everyone. My favorite part was Jahren and Bill's time in the Arctic, digging up ancient trees. I really enjoyed that scene of Bill dancing, and her description of it. 3.5 stars

I def recommend the audiobook! Hope Jahren reads it herself and you can really feel the emotion as she tells you her life story. I always enjoy listening to women in science talk about their work and their experience navigating the field when especially in the past, men were lauded and revered for their accomplishments and women really had to fight for everything. The only thing I‚Äôd say which is entirely. a personal thing is that I don‚Äôt naturally gravitate toward her field and don‚Äôt find it super compelling but the way she told it made me infinitely more interested so no negatives there.
This is simply brilliant.From the idea, to the writing, to the narration, and all the feelings it awakes makes writing a review useless in my opinion. JUST GO READ IT YOURSELF!

My rating for this book is a reflection not so much of my enjoyment of it as my acknowledgement of its importance. Hope Jahren is a successful female research scientist working within a STEM field that's still overwhelmingly male-dominated, a woman with mental illness who has been able to forge an academic career‚Äîvoices like hers are too rarely heard in academia in general and STEM fields in particular. Jahren focuses less on the highs of her career (she's won multiple Fulbrights, for instance, but I'm not sure that she even mentions that in the book) than she does on the lows and even more so the monotonous middle: the antisocial hours spent doing repetitive prep work in the lab, the constant scrabble to secure funding, the gauntlet of aggressions (micro and macro) faced by women in academia.However, for all Jahren's ability to be very upfront about her experiences (she clearly prides herself on her bluntness), Lab Girl is the kind of memoir that suffers from the author's lack of self-awareness. Although I'm not in a STEM field, I am a woman in academia, and so I'm quite familiar with other women (almost always white women) like Jahren: women for whom sexism is odious inasmuch as it affects them, but who care not one jot about systemic sexism or how it affects other women. Almost the only women to feature in the book are Jahren and her mother (who is treated with a hostility which I find inexplicable, given that nothing in the behaviour attributed to her seems particularly egregious or all that different from that ascribed to Jahren's beloved father), and I was almost surprised to end a book not having encountered a paragraph in which Jahren explains why she's Not Like the Other Girls. More overtly jarring were Jahren's descriptions of her interactions with students and the means by which she "trains in" new graduate students. If these were the anecdotes she thought made her look like a competent instructor, I'm hoping her grad students have insurance which lets them access a good therapist‚Äîor failing that, that they have access to a steady supply of palatable beer. Don't haze your students! Don't pass on fucked-up measures of academic "worth" to students just because academia is messed up and most graduate advisors don't know pedagogical theory from a hole in the wall!Listening to this as an audiobook was also a mistake. Jahren's talents are undoubtedly many, but acting out even her own words is not one she possesses. The vocal quivering and gulping she employed were distracting and maudlin; it was like listening to an audiobook from the Victorian period. Listening to the audiobook version also made the section set in Ireland extra obnoxious to me (an Irishwoman), and retroactively made me question the trustworthiness of great swathes of the book. The most egregious example of this is when Jahren describes getting lost in Limerick City, and attributes this to the fact that all of the street signs are in Irish. (Now, I've heard Americans mangle Irish over the years, but never so comprehensively as Hope Jahren. I honestly asked myself if she'd just spoken in Klingon, had to go look up the text of the book on Google Books, and then shrieked at the realisation that she was trying to say "Sr√°id Eibhl√≠n.) Here's the thing: street signs in Ireland are bilingual, with the English-language text generally appearing in larger font, and the Irish-language version smaller and in italics. There's no way that Jahren was lost and distractedly trying to figure out where "Sr√°id Eibhl√≠n" was; she had to have known all along that she was on Ellen Street. This might seem like nitpicking, but such an obvious twisting of the truth‚Äîwhether in service of a little bit of drama or getting an extra bit of comedy out of the Weird Irish‚Äîfelt like the literary version of the bad scientific practice of p-hacking.

This was excellent. From the beautiful writing about her family, or of her struggles with building and maintaining a lab, or her long friendship with colleague Bill, or of her struggles with bipolar disorder, or the lyrical sections about plant life, I thoroughly enjoyed this memoir. I was fascinated, and listened, rapt, though the many events of Hope Jahren's life, and I learned some great things too, about the glorious plants on this planet that we couldn't exist without.

I give this memoir 3 stars. Pros:‚Ä¢	Her descriptions of how plants and trees grow were in general fabulous. Terribly complicated biology and she was able to describe it in language that was not condescending but just was utterly fascinating. She explained a number of biological phenomena throughout the book and her explanations in most cases at least for me were just at about the right length...long enough so I could understand the basic phenomenon but not so long as to make me lose interest. So kudos to her for that. ‚Ä¢	Her descriptions of her mania and depression were scary-sad. It‚Äôs obvious she had some major hurdles in her life that her own body were creating for her‚Ä¶I am glad that she is at the position she is at today‚Ä¶ Her troubles reminded me of the memoir, An Unquiet Mind, by Kay Redfield Jamison, a psychologist who herself had bipolar disorder (which I highly recommend GR folks to read). ‚Ä¢	Dr. Jahren‚Äôs description of growing up and her going to her father‚Äôs lab was quite interesting, as well as the family dynamics (and sometimes lack thereof‚Ä¶.there was not a lot of overt affection that her parents showed her apparently and she also was not close to her brothers). In a later part of the book she made a comment that ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know if I was crying because I was nobody‚Äôs wife or mother ‚Äì or because I felt like nobody‚Äôs daughter‚Äì‚Ä¶‚Äù. So it appeared she had next to no relationship with her family after she left home for grad school and beyond, yet there is this book dedication which seemed odd at least to me: ‚ÄúEverything I write is dedicated to my mother.‚Äù‚Ä¢	Her description of academia is for the most part (I am in and come from academia) realistic. She for many a year lived on what is called ‚Äúsoft money‚Äù in which her lab was dependent on governmental grants. ‚ÄúHer lab‚Äù means her salary and her assistants‚Äô salaries and money needed to conduct her experiments. One is always having to write research grants (with no guarantee that a particular grant will ever get funded), because the money always seems to be running out. And that‚Äôs OK in a way‚Ä¶there is no free lunch‚Ä¶but still it is stressful not only for principal investigators but those working for them (in this memoir for example, Bill her lab manager).Cons:‚Ä¢	The book was way too long for its own good. ‚Ä¢	Some of the long drawn-out conversations between her and her comrade-in-arms Bill that she relates to us could have been either shortened or deleted. She wrote the conversations in a verbatim style as if they just happened yesterday when in many instances the conversations happened in the late 1990s or early 2000s. Some of the conversations were ‚Äúdopey‚Äù for lack of a better word ‚Äì people just do not talk like that. ‚Ä¢	I really did not like Bill. Just my problem I guess. He appeared to be satisfied working 80-hour weeks, not having a life outside of the lab, working apparently at times on starvation wages, literally living in the lab building at times, living in a van‚Ä¶ She portrays him as some sort of hero to her‚Ä¶he never grew on me. To me he had an anti-social personality. And he sure swore a lot. ‚Ä¢	She is introducing us to a scientific field, plant biology, and she does a fantastic job. But there was one part of the book that just got me pissed off. It‚Äôs when she and her lab visited a place that housed monkeys called the Monkey Jungle. And what she did, as an esteemed scientist, was anthropomorphize the primates to an extent in which it was in one respect laughable (not funny laughable), but in another respect a disservice to both the animals and to science (‚Äú‚Ä¶she saw in Monkey Jungle a doppelganger for her lab‚Äù). ‚Äú‚Ä¶Two small squirrel monkeys seemed to be trapped in their own private Samuel Beckett play, caught in a web made of equal parts dependence and loathing. ‚Ä¶ A single howler monkey sat high on a branch in the back, wailing out the entire Book of Job in his native tongue while periodically raising his arms in an age-old supplication for an explanation as to why the righteous must suffer.‚Äù Went beyond the pale for me.Reviews:https://www.theguardian.com/books/201... https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/29/bo...

'Science is work, nothing more and nothing less. And so we will keep working as another day dawns and this week turns into next week, and then this month becomes next month. I can feel the warmth of the same brilliant sun that shines above the forest and onto the green world, but in my heart I know that I am not a plant. I am more like an ant, driven to find and carry single dead needles, one after the other, all the way across the forest and then add them one by one to a pile so massive that I can only fully imagine one small corner of it.' (p. 277)This book was such a joy. A part memoir, part ode to plant life and the grind of a scientist, written so engagingly that you can't help but feel ready to kick off your shoes, then step right into the soil to collect some samples to label the next thousand times over. That's a lot coming from me. As much as I can appreciate nature, I'm far from being outdoorsy, with my city living and my rampant fear of bugs. Hope Jahren allows us all to feel like we have that curiosity inside us to be scientists in our own lives, in small but by no means insignificant ways. She burns with such infectious passion for her work that you can't help but be drawn in too. The book's journey is divided lovingly into: Roots and Leaves, Wood and Knots, and Flowers and Fruit, with individual chapters then going into her work and rhapsodies of the wonder of nature that it all around us (have you looked at a leaf lately and thought about how miraculous it is?), then somehow works it all in with her personal life and her relationship with Bill, which is utterly undefinable in the most wonderful of ways. Here's one of the many, many plant-related passages that I loved, which described not just nature but her and Bill:'Why are they together, the tree and the fungus? We don't know. The fungus could certainly live very well alone almost anywhere, but it chooses to entwine itself with the tree over an easier and more independent life. It has adapted to seek the rush of pure sweetness that comes directly from a plant root, such a strange and concentrated compound, unlike anything to be found elsewhere in the forest. And perhaps the fungus can somehow sense that when it is part of a symbiosis, it is also not alone.' (p. 105)I suppose a caveat is in order: for those readers who aren't too interested in the science, it can be a bit tedious and may lose you a bit if you haven't been in a science class since high school, however the enthusiasm and dedication that Jahren has will win you over. I felt comforted reading about all her experiments out in the fields and how meticulously everything had to be done, and then rejoiced when results came through that led to conclusions and consequently, more funding! You'll root (ha!) for her and Bill every step of the way. She's also quite honest about her struggles, not just at work but at home as well, which I didn't expect. It's very difficult to admit to desperate times when you can't see what's ahead of you, or loneliness, much less mental health struggles. I appreciated the book even more for Jahren's willingness to talk about all this and the vulnerability that comes with it. A very moving memoir. It may surprise you how much you will want to read about the inner workings and patience of a seed, or how the surprisingly softness of spongy moss led to a way of finding solid people to work with, until you pick this up, and then it doesn't. It just feels right to see the world like this.

Reading the beginning of Lab Girl by Hope Jahren through The First Look Book Club I was charmed by Jahren's voice and put the book on my 'to read' list. When I saw it on the new book shelf at the library I brought it home with me."Each beginning is the end of a waiting. We are each given exactly one chance to be. Each of us is both impossible and inevitable. Every replete tree was first a seed that waited."Jahren has faced many challenges: a lonely childhood, working herself through school, struggling as a female scientist against the prejudices of a male dominated field, finding funding for her projects. Her success can be verified by her choice as one of Time's 100 Most Influential People, her Fulbright Scholarships, and her long relationship with her lab partner Bill. She found love and faced a difficult pregnancy sans medication for her bipolar disorder to have the child that changed her life."I have learned that raising a child is essentially one long, slow agony of letting go."Jahren's writing is so lovely to read. Her love of her work as a geobioloist and her awe of nature shines through the pages. She alternates chapters on her life with chapters about the world of green growing things around us.The self-portrait Jahren paints reveals her personal challenges and insecurities without being confessional and raw. Her lab partner/best friend/soul mate Bill is interesting and complicated, eccentric and brilliant. He once lived in a hole in his parent's back yard. We come to love him as much as Jahren does. We are happy when her loneliness is ended by marrying a man who 'gets her.'To read a section of the book go to http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/boo...To read an interview with Jahren go to http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/the-se...

In my mind, a great memoir has you singing along with the writer when she is happy, and aching with her when she is sad. Hope Jahren's excellent memoir Lab Girl does just that. Jahren intersperses stories about plants with stories about science with stories about her own life in a way that is masterful and utterly engaging. I didn't expect to enjoy reading about plants or to learn about them (I'm an ecologist) but I found myself loving those sections. Jahren's unique insights into why it is important to understand how plants grow add a fascinating layer to what in lesser hands might have been 'just biology'. The stories about science illuminate how science really works - what it takes to get money to do the work, and how it all really unfolds in the lab. And the stories about Jahren's life and how her choices led her to be the person she is bring the book together as a complete whole.As Heather says, this is a book for those who love science or memoir. But it is also a book for all those who simply love well-crafted stories about courageous lives and courageous women and learning how to be a good person in a complex world.

Fascinating read that is hard to parse. Is it about a female scientist? A relationship between a man and a woman like no other? Manic depression? Botany?The author really holds nothing back in this memoir, and I found Hope to be pretty fascinating. She's nerdy and mentally ill and loving and a workaholic. She is an incredible scientist and a tremendous writer. For me, the highlight of this book is her description of her relationship with her lab employee (partner?), Bill. I couldn't decide what to make of it. Were they in love? Like siblings? Just great colleagues with a shared passion for the work? Whatever it is/was, it was very interesting.In addition, the structure of the book is well done. The reader alternately learns something about plant life, and then the subsequent chapter highlights parallels in human life. I have little science background, but thought most of the explanations were clear and educational. I imagine Hope is an excellent teacher, with the ability to both be engaging and impart knowledge at the same time.Really, almost a five star read for me.

I ended up DNF-ing this one at 200pages in (which I know is fairly close to the end). I actually loved the science-y bits of this, where the author shows her flair for studying plants, her passion for their care, and also her stunning ability to write beautifully about them. However, although I think these sections were great, Hope Jahren's actual backstory and the way she wrote about her journey just didn't 'click' with me and I found it super hard to connect or relate at all. This really took me out of the book and so ultimately I was forcing myself to pick it up, and that's no fun, so I just decided it was time to put it down and give it to someone else who may enjoy it far more. Ah well.
Jahren's book is full of passion and love for her family, friends and work. It is a memoir of sorts with the life cycle of a tree interspersed with her own stories. A fantastic read!

I finished this memoir a few days ago and in trying to get my thoughts together for a review, I read what my GR friends said about the book, and I realized it's all been said and said so much better and eloquently than I could.So I'll just say I loved it. I listened to the audiobook, read by the author , and she does an excellent job. I loved hearing about her life and passion as a scientist, her illness (bipolar), her quirky friend Bill, her marriage, motherhood, and yes, I even loved the science-y parts. I'll never look at a tree the same and I now have even more respect for research scientists.Highly recommended.

I waited for a long time to read this book even though it came highly recommended from several scientists. I was skeptical about the title. And while I am not a scientist by profession, I did train as an undergrad and earn a BS. The thing about scientists is we are very territorial. I am a Chemist. My Physicist friends say, "But Chemistry is all Physics!" and they are not entirely wrong. I often scoff at Biology, Botany, Zoology, etc. and say, "But you're ignoring all the Chemistry!" So the Botany angle here did not move it up my TBR list.But. As a baby scientist myself, and as someone who spent several years married to a scientist during his PhD and basically lived and breathed lab culture, ultimately I couldn't stay away. I had to see what all the fuss about and I had to see if Jahren got it right. Many people don't. If you are intimidated by a very scientific read, don't be afraid. Jahren's years of teaching experience have clearly created someone who is skilled at turning complex scientific processes and ideas into easily digestible narratives. If you are concerned it will not be scientific enough, there's enough interesting data here to sate you, though I did wish I learned more about Jahren's own research.The thing about this book, though, the thing that makes it one of my favorites of the year isn't just that Jahren gets lab life right, it's how skillfully she tells the stories of trees alongside her own story. I have never ever cared about a tree more than I did during this book. And I was lucky enough to listen to the audio (read beautifully by Jahren herself) while I drove past the blazing autumn leaves of New England, so every tree seemed somehow magical. If someone had taught me about plants the way Jahren does, where it is not just a process to learn and a life cycle to memorize, but where every single step along the way is a miracle in and of itself, I can see myself seriously considering Botany as a potential major. This book in the hands of a college student could be life changing.Some may find Jahren's story not interesting enough for a memoir. But this is not a memoir that is built around a journey. It is showing you who she is, and a big part of it focuses on the incredibly close relationship she has with her lab partner, Bill. While they mean absolutely everything to one another, they are not intimate friends, not secret sharers, not confidants. Learning the rhythms of their conversation and the routines of their friendship will show you the kind of relationship you probably haven't seen before. Jahren covers many things here besides science. Parenthood, the chill Scandinavian traditions of the Midwest, the slog of early academic life, and her own struggle with bipolar disorder. Her writing is simple but deliberate and lovely. I enjoyed every moment listening to her read.

My first thoughts, this book is in a word, odd. It is a memoir written by a bipolar paleobiologist and her Asperger‚Äôs like, one-handed best friend/lab assistant. They stumble through the US and Europe trying to do good science. The book is about three things. 1. Science: we learn about the scientific method, how a mass spectrometer works, and that trees have memory (all of which was much more interesting than I would have thought). 2. Love and Family: in all its permutations, good/bad, expressed/unexpressed, chosen/not chosen. 3. Academia: a close and accurate look at the tarnished Ivory tower with tales of sexism, cut throat competition, and the never ending search for money. Despite her struggles, she becomes an award winning and accomplished scholar with her best friend by her side. My final thoughts: this book is in a word, captivating.

What a shame this utterly amazing book has such a lame title. My advice is to forget the title and read the book. Jahren, a three-time Fulbright winner, has written a reader-friendly, relationship-centered sequence of stories about her experience as a paleobotany researcher. There is much to learn and Jahren doesn't shrink from explaining it. However, the terms and structure are highly accessible. The book is one of those rare fusions of science and humanity that many readers so often wish for but can seldom find. The reason is simple--it takes a polymath like Ms. Jahren to understand and love the labwork and yet also be able to explain it to non-scientists. This is the biology class--really much more--you wish you'd experienced. At the same time, Jahren is clear about the difficulties of an academic scientist's life--getting grants, writing proposals, acquiring equipment, paying lab assistants, the necessity of moving on to better opportunities. She writes with joy about marriage, her son, her struggle with bipolarity, and most of all about her talented, brilliant assistant, Bill.About the title: this is apparently the season of "The Girl Who..." after the success of The Girl on the Train. Unfortunately, "Lab GIRL" is diminutive, and diminishes, the complex, warm, fascinating PhD scientist we meet in its pages. I wish the publishers had worked harder to come up with a title that better represents this story.
An uneven read for me. Loved the science-y bits, found the personal memoir sections either tedious or grating.

This is a textbook case of 'it's not you, it's me.' I understand the appeal, and in a lot of ways I'm thrilled about this book's mainstream success (women in STEM fields and healthy, platonic relationships between men and women are two things we need more of in media), but there were only so many loving descriptions of trees I could take after a while. There was just too much science and not enough human interest to keep me engaged, and while I wouldn't say you need to be knowledgeable about biology to approach this book, a certain amount of interest would be helpful, and I just don't have that, at all. And the audiobook was a mistake; the author narrates it with a positively bizarre amount of melodrama (like, actually in tears at multiple points, and I'm sorry if that makes me sound callous but I really don't react well to overly sentimental narration), so I can't say it was a pleasant listening experience... But anyway, really not a bad book, just not my kind of book.

I love a book that educates me in a non-painful way. Jahren alternates chapters between her journey as a scientist and her knowledge and passion for botany. Of special interest to me was reading about the difficulties she faced especially as a Research Botanist. Some readers in my book club found her whiny, but I thought she was just being honest in her struggles with an antiseptic upbringing, mental illness, and sexist road blocks from being a woman in a male dominated fields. I learned it takes a really special person to do research experiments.The tension to me of mind numbing monotonous tasks coupled with the stringent standards of proof, well let's just say it's not a field for most people. Added to that is the constant struggle for adequate funding. I found it quite enjoyable with bonus botanic bits.

I bought this book because it was a good deal, wondering if I would ever read it. What a surprise! It is a great combination of life and science. I found it very interesting and will never look at trees or plants in the same way.
I might never look at a trees and plants the same way. Seriously thinking about planting my own oak tree on the back yard and watch it grow.

3 1/2 starsI have always had a love of medicine and science (all though my high school results on science may tell another story) so I was immediately drawn to this book.Hope grew up in her father‚Äôs laboratory surrounded by Bunsen burners, petri dishes and access to everything a curious child my want to investigate in a lab. It‚Äôs not surprising that she was brought up in an academically focused household and even her mother studied part time and included her daughter in her learning process.I really appreciated the fact that all the experiments or processes in the book was explained so that any person no matter how unenlightened about science, could grasp the concepts.‚ÄùMy laboratory is like a church because it is where I figure out what I believe‚ÄùI loved reading about her part-time work at a local hospital while studying ‚Äì it gave me glimpses of the nuts and bolts of running a hospital and more than once I wished that she had become a doctor rather than a botanist.My feelings towards flora is neither here nor there so naturally some of the chapters dealing with the workings of plants didn‚Äôt really interest me but one thing came across crystal clear and that is her absolute passion about what she does for a living.  ‚ÄúI will never stop being ravenously hungry for science, no matter how well it feeds me‚ÄùI also found the sections dealing with just how difficult it is to secure funding for scientific projects are as well as glimpses on Hope dealing with her bi-polar disease, eye-opening. But it‚Äôs her friendship with Bill, her lab partner, that stood out for me. So this is a mix between work as a scientist, information about botany and a young woman trying to carve a foothold for herself in a male dominated industry. This may not be for everyone but it was a very enjoyable and informative read for me.
Enjoyable and really interesting. Loved all the science!

I'm very curious what other scientists, particularly women, think of this book. To me, the best writing in the book was in the short chapters about plants, even though some of the cool plant insights were already familiar to me since I've worked in plant labs for some years. The rest was uneven, tended toward telling instead of showing, and I think because of this the relationships come out feeling flat, even her relationship with Bill which is clearly important and meant to feel more three-dimensional. Overall, although I certainly support women in science telling their stories, this didn't live up to my expectations, not even close, and I would take Evelyn Fox Keller's 'A Feeling for the Organism' or Susan Brind Morrow's 'Wolves and Honey' or Lauren Redniss's 'Radioactive' over Lab Girl any day of the week. One more note: Jahren sometimes explicitly or implicitly gives the impression that there's one correct way to be a scientist: you have to be immediately driven forward by your failures, never discouraged by them, you have to be able to work for 48 hours straight, you have to have always known science is what you wanted. There is no one way to be a scientist: this is completely untrue, as it is untrue of any profession, and don't let it discourage you or any young girl you know from pursuing science.

Such a short book, but it took me forever to read it. I should have liked it more than I actually did. Hope Jahren's part-memoir, part-scientific reflection has humour, memorable personalities, fun educational material, and some truly moving recollections. The problem was that sometimes Jahren's could become too dramatic. I had the misfortune to listen to the audiobook while walking my dog, and I swear it made me want to pull my hair out. The teary, choking voice at the end of nearly every chapter that was supposed to make me feel emotions while the author dwelled in self-pity was like nails on chalkboard. I also went into the book thinking this would be more of a love letter to botany and some interesting findings the author discovered during her career (I never read blurbs), but instead I got mostly a memoir, interlaced some musings on plants that supported the mood for these memories. And this is officially the longest sentence I've ever written. Needless to say, I am sort of underwhelmed. If you are going to read Lab Girl, please avoid the audio, and be prepared for a lifetime worth of over-reactions to ordinary events.

When you write your own memoirs, you can write anything you want - it's your life, or your own stories of your own life. So I can't really fault Hope for telling her story. But I can caution potential readers: if you want to know what's it is like to be a scientist, don't rely on this book. This is just one story, and it is not at all typical. You don't have to work 80 hours per week to be a scientist. You can have a life AND be a scientist. If you're a student, you can find a grad advisor who cares about you and invests in your success and doesn't haze you when you first join the lab. In short, Future Scientists, don't be discouraged by reading this. Science takes all kinds, and life in science can be what you want it to be.

I like to read non-fiction books as a change of pace from my reading fiction titles. My wife's reading group selected Lab Girl, so I gave it a read, too. Hope is a "tree scientist," and she brings a deep passion to her work. I learned all types of new stuff about trees and plants. I like how she writes about her personal life, including her career in academia. Great read.

5 Heartfelt Stars: Achingly beautiful and illuminating "Descending into and then surfacing from winter formed the driving rhythm of our lives."Beautifully written, this books blends together a perfect cadence of science and memoir. Rhythm and cycles permeate the narrative, bouncing between Hope Jahren's ups and downs as a career scientist, and the intricate lives of vegetation. I hadn't even read a synopsis before before I began, and was pleasantly surprised by the delicate unfolding of the book ‚Ä¶ made from paper, derived from intelligent trees ‚Ä¶ ~ Just Trust Me: In Praise Of Strange Books (All 3 are 5 star reads!)~Hope Jahren is a celebrated geochemist and geobiologist, not to mention an exceptionally interesting human being. Currently she works at the University of Oslo, and this book is her origin story.Jahren worked with her mother in the garden growing up, first sparking her love of growing things.‚ÄúBy the end of June the whole crop was well on its way and the world around us was so green that it seemed impossible that it could ever have been otherwise. By July, the sweating leaves of all these plants had pumped the air so full of moisture that the humidity caused the electrical lines to buzz and crackle overhead.‚Äù She also played in her father‚Äôs lab from a young age, inspiring her love for science and hunger to know how things work.‚ÄúThere I transformed from a girl into a scientist, just like Peter Parker becoming Spider-Man, only kind of backward.‚Äù Eventually, Jahren‚Äôs life intersects with a man named Bill, in a lab‚Äîwhere else? He becomes her loyal assistant, moving locations and building labs with her. There was one point where I kind of hoped they‚Äôd get together, but their relationship is unique and special‚Äîmore like best friends or brother and sister.Did I mention the writing is beautiful? Jahren deals with mental illness and loneliness in such a heartfelt manner it‚Äôs impossible not to empathize alongside her. She reads the audiobook and you can hear the emotion in her voice, bleeding through the words. The tone remains positive and manages not to be depressing even when dealing with tough topics. There is hope, and the beauty of science unveiling new understanding to the world. The history and lives of trees are presented in a fascinating way, paralleling various aspects of human lives.If you enjoy plants and true tails of scientific superstars ‚Äî this book is for you.Quotes:‚ÄúShe set her hair in curlers while listening to records of Carl Sandburg‚Äôs poems over and over, and instructed me on how to hear the words differently each time. After discovering Susan Sontag, she explained to me that even meaning itself is a constructed concept, and I learned how to nod and pretend to understand.‚Äù ‚ÄúFull-blown mania lets you see the other side of death. Its onset is profoundly visceral and unexpected, no matter how many times you‚Äôve been through it. It is your body that first senses the urgency of a new world about to bloom. Your vertebrae seem to detach from one another and you elongate as if toward the sun‚Äôs light. You can‚Äôt hear above the sloshing roar of blood pushed through your head by some impossibly sustained orgasm within your beating heart. For the next twenty-four, forty-eight, seventy-two hours you will have to yell to hear yourself over this whooshing. Nothing, nothing can be loud enough or bright enough or move fast enough. The world appears as if through a fish-eye lens; your view is fuzzy with sparkling edges. You have received a grand, systemic injection of Novocain and your entire body tingles briefly before it becomes flaccidly foreign and unreal. Your raised arms are the fleshy petals of a magnificent lily bursting into flower. It deeply dawns on you that this new world about to bloom is you.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere at the end of the world, he danced in the broad and endless daylight, and I accepted him for what he was, instead of what he wished he could be. The potency of my acceptance made me wonder, just a little, if I could turn it inward and accept myself.‚Äù

This memoir could be subtitled ‚ÄúThe Private Lives of Plants,‚Äù because paleobiologist Hope Jahren can‚Äôt help but wax poetic at times about her chosen field of study, with which she is clearly enraptured. Fortunately, she‚Äôs pretty convincing. Since my tastes run more toward gossipy tell-alls than science texts, my favorite parts of Lab Girl were Jahren's personal stories of her romance with her husband and decidedly unromantic relationship with her (occasionally homeless but forever loyal) research partner Bill. Amazingly enough, though, I didn't glaze over during the parts about trees and mosses. Jahren is one of those rare scientists able to express her enthusiasm for her subject in a way that translates to the average Jane. The audio version is read by Jahren herself, which makes the more emotional parts of the book ring with authenticity, but if you're bothered by soft, whispery voices, you might prefer to pick up this one in print. If you close your eyes, Jahren sounds just like Ana Gasteyer's character from the classic SNL sketch ‚ÄúSchweddy Balls.‚ÄùMore book recommendations by me at www.readingwithhippos.com

The name of this book never worked for me - it didn't seem to capture what the book was about, and it is diminuitive in nature. Jahren is not a "girl", and this book is not cutesy, as the title, and even the cover art, would lead you to believe. Jahren's work in geobotany is fascinating, and I really enjoyed the interspersed chapters on plants, trees, natural history. The personal memoir sections were okay - they showed devotion and commitment to the science. I was frustrated with the roadblocks and glass ceilings that Jahren hit/endured as a female scientist, but I was also grew frustrated with Jahren for her continuous lack of foresight and planning, and the ways her actions (and inactions) impacted those around her. I know these symptoms are directly tied to her mental illness, and she writes about that with candor and bravery, and I do agree that we need more of this - normalizing, familiarizing. Thankfully, with time and experience, things did get better - for everyone. My favorite part was Jahren and Bill's time in the Arctic, digging up ancient trees. I really enjoyed that scene of Bill dancing, and her description of it. 3.5 stars

I def recommend the audiobook! Hope Jahren reads it herself and you can really feel the emotion as she tells you her life story. I always enjoy listening to women in science talk about their work and their experience navigating the field when especially in the past, men were lauded and revered for their accomplishments and women really had to fight for everything. The only thing I‚Äôd say which is entirely. a personal thing is that I don‚Äôt naturally gravitate toward her field and don‚Äôt find it super compelling but the way she told it made me infinitely more interested so no negatives there.
This is simply brilliant.From the idea, to the writing, to the narration, and all the feelings it awakes makes writing a review useless in my opinion. JUST GO READ IT YOURSELF!

My rating for this book is a reflection not so much of my enjoyment of it as my acknowledgement of its importance. Hope Jahren is a successful female research scientist working within a STEM field that's still overwhelmingly male-dominated, a woman with mental illness who has been able to forge an academic career‚Äîvoices like hers are too rarely heard in academia in general and STEM fields in particular. Jahren focuses less on the highs of her career (she's won multiple Fulbrights, for instance, but I'm not sure that she even mentions that in the book) than she does on the lows and even more so the monotonous middle: the antisocial hours spent doing repetitive prep work in the lab, the constant scrabble to secure funding, the gauntlet of aggressions (micro and macro) faced by women in academia.However, for all Jahren's ability to be very upfront about her experiences (she clearly prides herself on her bluntness), Lab Girl is the kind of memoir that suffers from the author's lack of self-awareness. Although I'm not in a STEM field, I am a woman in academia, and so I'm quite familiar with other women (almost always white women) like Jahren: women for whom sexism is odious inasmuch as it affects them, but who care not one jot about systemic sexism or how it affects other women. Almost the only women to feature in the book are Jahren and her mother (who is treated with a hostility which I find inexplicable, given that nothing in the behaviour attributed to her seems particularly egregious or all that different from that ascribed to Jahren's beloved father), and I was almost surprised to end a book not having encountered a paragraph in which Jahren explains why she's Not Like the Other Girls. More overtly jarring were Jahren's descriptions of her interactions with students and the means by which she "trains in" new graduate students. If these were the anecdotes she thought made her look like a competent instructor, I'm hoping her grad students have insurance which lets them access a good therapist‚Äîor failing that, that they have access to a steady supply of palatable beer. Don't haze your students! Don't pass on fucked-up measures of academic "worth" to students just because academia is messed up and most graduate advisors don't know pedagogical theory from a hole in the wall!Listening to this as an audiobook was also a mistake. Jahren's talents are undoubtedly many, but acting out even her own words is not one she possesses. The vocal quivering and gulping she employed were distracting and maudlin; it was like listening to an audiobook from the Victorian period. Listening to the audiobook version also made the section set in Ireland extra obnoxious to me (an Irishwoman), and retroactively made me question the trustworthiness of great swathes of the book. The most egregious example of this is when Jahren describes getting lost in Limerick City, and attributes this to the fact that all of the street signs are in Irish. (Now, I've heard Americans mangle Irish over the years, but never so comprehensively as Hope Jahren. I honestly asked myself if she'd just spoken in Klingon, had to go look up the text of the book on Google Books, and then shrieked at the realisation that she was trying to say "Sr√°id Eibhl√≠n.) Here's the thing: street signs in Ireland are bilingual, with the English-language text generally appearing in larger font, and the Irish-language version smaller and in italics. There's no way that Jahren was lost and distractedly trying to figure out where "Sr√°id Eibhl√≠n" was; she had to have known all along that she was on Ellen Street. This might seem like nitpicking, but such an obvious twisting of the truth‚Äîwhether in service of a little bit of drama or getting an extra bit of comedy out of the Weird Irish‚Äîfelt like the literary version of the bad scientific practice of p-hacking.

This was excellent. From the beautiful writing about her family, or of her struggles with building and maintaining a lab, or her long friendship with colleague Bill, or of her struggles with bipolar disorder, or the lyrical sections about plant life, I thoroughly enjoyed this memoir. I was fascinated, and listened, rapt, though the many events of Hope Jahren's life, and I learned some great things too, about the glorious plants on this planet that we couldn't exist without.

I give this memoir 3 stars. Pros:‚Ä¢	Her descriptions of how plants and trees grow were in general fabulous. Terribly complicated biology and she was able to describe it in language that was not condescending but just was utterly fascinating. She explained a number of biological phenomena throughout the book and her explanations in most cases at least for me were just at about the right length...long enough so I could understand the basic phenomenon but not so long as to make me lose interest. So kudos to her for that. ‚Ä¢	Her descriptions of her mania and depression were scary-sad. It‚Äôs obvious she had some major hurdles in her life that her own body were creating for her‚Ä¶I am glad that she is at the position she is at today‚Ä¶ Her troubles reminded me of the memoir, An Unquiet Mind, by Kay Redfield Jamison, a psychologist who herself had bipolar disorder (which I highly recommend GR folks to read). ‚Ä¢	Dr. Jahren‚Äôs description of growing up and her going to her father‚Äôs lab was quite interesting, as well as the family dynamics (and sometimes lack thereof‚Ä¶.there was not a lot of overt affection that her parents showed her apparently and she also was not close to her brothers). In a later part of the book she made a comment that ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know if I was crying because I was nobody‚Äôs wife or mother ‚Äì or because I felt like nobody‚Äôs daughter‚Äì‚Ä¶‚Äù. So it appeared she had next to no relationship with her family after she left home for grad school and beyond, yet there is this book dedication which seemed odd at least to me: ‚ÄúEverything I write is dedicated to my mother.‚Äù‚Ä¢	Her description of academia is for the most part (I am in and come from academia) realistic. She for many a year lived on what is called ‚Äúsoft money‚Äù in which her lab was dependent on governmental grants. ‚ÄúHer lab‚Äù means her salary and her assistants‚Äô salaries and money needed to conduct her experiments. One is always having to write research grants (with no guarantee that a particular grant will ever get funded), because the money always seems to be running out. And that‚Äôs OK in a way‚Ä¶there is no free lunch‚Ä¶but still it is stressful not only for principal investigators but those working for them (in this memoir for example, Bill her lab manager).Cons:‚Ä¢	The book was way too long for its own good. ‚Ä¢	Some of the long drawn-out conversations between her and her comrade-in-arms Bill that she relates to us could have been either shortened or deleted. She wrote the conversations in a verbatim style as if they just happened yesterday when in many instances the conversations happened in the late 1990s or early 2000s. Some of the conversations were ‚Äúdopey‚Äù for lack of a better word ‚Äì people just do not talk like that. ‚Ä¢	I really did not like Bill. Just my problem I guess. He appeared to be satisfied working 80-hour weeks, not having a life outside of the lab, working apparently at times on starvation wages, literally living in the lab building at times, living in a van‚Ä¶ She portrays him as some sort of hero to her‚Ä¶he never grew on me. To me he had an anti-social personality. And he sure swore a lot. ‚Ä¢	She is introducing us to a scientific field, plant biology, and she does a fantastic job. But there was one part of the book that just got me pissed off. It‚Äôs when she and her lab visited a place that housed monkeys called the Monkey Jungle. And what she did, as an esteemed scientist, was anthropomorphize the primates to an extent in which it was in one respect laughable (not funny laughable), but in another respect a disservice to both the animals and to science (‚Äú‚Ä¶she saw in Monkey Jungle a doppelganger for her lab‚Äù). ‚Äú‚Ä¶Two small squirrel monkeys seemed to be trapped in their own private Samuel Beckett play, caught in a web made of equal parts dependence and loathing. ‚Ä¶ A single howler monkey sat high on a branch in the back, wailing out the entire Book of Job in his native tongue while periodically raising his arms in an age-old supplication for an explanation as to why the righteous must suffer.‚Äù Went beyond the pale for me.Reviews:https://www.theguardian.com/books/201... https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/29/bo...

'Science is work, nothing more and nothing less. And so we will keep working as another day dawns and this week turns into next week, and then this month becomes next month. I can feel the warmth of the same brilliant sun that shines above the forest and onto the green world, but in my heart I know that I am not a plant. I am more like an ant, driven to find and carry single dead needles, one after the other, all the way across the forest and then add them one by one to a pile so massive that I can only fully imagine one small corner of it.' (p. 277)This book was such a joy. A part memoir, part ode to plant life and the grind of a scientist, written so engagingly that you can't help but feel ready to kick off your shoes, then step right into the soil to collect some samples to label the next thousand times over. That's a lot coming from me. As much as I can appreciate nature, I'm far from being outdoorsy, with my city living and my rampant fear of bugs. Hope Jahren allows us all to feel like we have that curiosity inside us to be scientists in our own lives, in small but by no means insignificant ways. She burns with such infectious passion for her work that you can't help but be drawn in too. The book's journey is divided lovingly into: Roots and Leaves, Wood and Knots, and Flowers and Fruit, with individual chapters then going into her work and rhapsodies of the wonder of nature that it all around us (have you looked at a leaf lately and thought about how miraculous it is?), then somehow works it all in with her personal life and her relationship with Bill, which is utterly undefinable in the most wonderful of ways. Here's one of the many, many plant-related passages that I loved, which described not just nature but her and Bill:'Why are they together, the tree and the fungus? We don't know. The fungus could certainly live very well alone almost anywhere, but it chooses to entwine itself with the tree over an easier and more independent life. It has adapted to seek the rush of pure sweetness that comes directly from a plant root, such a strange and concentrated compound, unlike anything to be found elsewhere in the forest. And perhaps the fungus can somehow sense that when it is part of a symbiosis, it is also not alone.' (p. 105)I suppose a caveat is in order: for those readers who aren't too interested in the science, it can be a bit tedious and may lose you a bit if you haven't been in a science class since high school, however the enthusiasm and dedication that Jahren has will win you over. I felt comforted reading about all her experiments out in the fields and how meticulously everything had to be done, and then rejoiced when results came through that led to conclusions and consequently, more funding! You'll root (ha!) for her and Bill every step of the way. She's also quite honest about her struggles, not just at work but at home as well, which I didn't expect. It's very difficult to admit to desperate times when you can't see what's ahead of you, or loneliness, much less mental health struggles. I appreciated the book even more for Jahren's willingness to talk about all this and the vulnerability that comes with it. A very moving memoir. It may surprise you how much you will want to read about the inner workings and patience of a seed, or how the surprisingly softness of spongy moss led to a way of finding solid people to work with, until you pick this up, and then it doesn't. It just feels right to see the world like this.

Reading the beginning of Lab Girl by Hope Jahren through The First Look Book Club I was charmed by Jahren's voice and put the book on my 'to read' list. When I saw it on the new book shelf at the library I brought it home with me."Each beginning is the end of a waiting. We are each given exactly one chance to be. Each of us is both impossible and inevitable. Every replete tree was first a seed that waited."Jahren has faced many challenges: a lonely childhood, working herself through school, struggling as a female scientist against the prejudices of a male dominated field, finding funding for her projects. Her success can be verified by her choice as one of Time's 100 Most Influential People, her Fulbright Scholarships, and her long relationship with her lab partner Bill. She found love and faced a difficult pregnancy sans medication for her bipolar disorder to have the child that changed her life."I have learned that raising a child is essentially one long, slow agony of letting go."Jahren's writing is so lovely to read. Her love of her work as a geobioloist and her awe of nature shines through the pages. She alternates chapters on her life with chapters about the world of green growing things around us.The self-portrait Jahren paints reveals her personal challenges and insecurities without being confessional and raw. Her lab partner/best friend/soul mate Bill is interesting and complicated, eccentric and brilliant. He once lived in a hole in his parent's back yard. We come to love him as much as Jahren does. We are happy when her loneliness is ended by marrying a man who 'gets her.'To read a section of the book go to http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/boo...To read an interview with Jahren go to http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/the-se...

In my mind, a great memoir has you singing along with the writer when she is happy, and aching with her when she is sad. Hope Jahren's excellent memoir Lab Girl does just that. Jahren intersperses stories about plants with stories about science with stories about her own life in a way that is masterful and utterly engaging. I didn't expect to enjoy reading about plants or to learn about them (I'm an ecologist) but I found myself loving those sections. Jahren's unique insights into why it is important to understand how plants grow add a fascinating layer to what in lesser hands might have been 'just biology'. The stories about science illuminate how science really works - what it takes to get money to do the work, and how it all really unfolds in the lab. And the stories about Jahren's life and how her choices led her to be the person she is bring the book together as a complete whole.As Heather says, this is a book for those who love science or memoir. But it is also a book for all those who simply love well-crafted stories about courageous lives and courageous women and learning how to be a good person in a complex world.

Fascinating read that is hard to parse. Is it about a female scientist? A relationship between a man and a woman like no other? Manic depression? Botany?The author really holds nothing back in this memoir, and I found Hope to be pretty fascinating. She's nerdy and mentally ill and loving and a workaholic. She is an incredible scientist and a tremendous writer. For me, the highlight of this book is her description of her relationship with her lab employee (partner?), Bill. I couldn't decide what to make of it. Were they in love? Like siblings? Just great colleagues with a shared passion for the work? Whatever it is/was, it was very interesting.In addition, the structure of the book is well done. The reader alternately learns something about plant life, and then the subsequent chapter highlights parallels in human life. I have little science background, but thought most of the explanations were clear and educational. I imagine Hope is an excellent teacher, with the ability to both be engaging and impart knowledge at the same time.Really, almost a five star read for me.

I ended up DNF-ing this one at 200pages in (which I know is fairly close to the end). I actually loved the science-y bits of this, where the author shows her flair for studying plants, her passion for their care, and also her stunning ability to write beautifully about them. However, although I think these sections were great, Hope Jahren's actual backstory and the way she wrote about her journey just didn't 'click' with me and I found it super hard to connect or relate at all. This really took me out of the book and so ultimately I was forcing myself to pick it up, and that's no fun, so I just decided it was time to put it down and give it to someone else who may enjoy it far more. Ah well.
Jahren's book is full of passion and love for her family, friends and work. It is a memoir of sorts with the life cycle of a tree interspersed with her own stories. A fantastic read!

I finished this memoir a few days ago and in trying to get my thoughts together for a review, I read what my GR friends said about the book, and I realized it's all been said and said so much better and eloquently than I could.So I'll just say I loved it. I listened to the audiobook, read by the author , and she does an excellent job. I loved hearing about her life and passion as a scientist, her illness (bipolar), her quirky friend Bill, her marriage, motherhood, and yes, I even loved the science-y parts. I'll never look at a tree the same and I now have even more respect for research scientists.Highly recommended.

I waited for a long time to read this book even though it came highly recommended from several scientists. I was skeptical about the title. And while I am not a scientist by profession, I did train as an undergrad and earn a BS. The thing about scientists is we are very territorial. I am a Chemist. My Physicist friends say, "But Chemistry is all Physics!" and they are not entirely wrong. I often scoff at Biology, Botany, Zoology, etc. and say, "But you're ignoring all the Chemistry!" So the Botany angle here did not move it up my TBR list.But. As a baby scientist myself, and as someone who spent several years married to a scientist during his PhD and basically lived and breathed lab culture, ultimately I couldn't stay away. I had to see what all the fuss about and I had to see if Jahren got it right. Many people don't. If you are intimidated by a very scientific read, don't be afraid. Jahren's years of teaching experience have clearly created someone who is skilled at turning complex scientific processes and ideas into easily digestible narratives. If you are concerned it will not be scientific enough, there's enough interesting data here to sate you, though I did wish I learned more about Jahren's own research.The thing about this book, though, the thing that makes it one of my favorites of the year isn't just that Jahren gets lab life right, it's how skillfully she tells the stories of trees alongside her own story. I have never ever cared about a tree more than I did during this book. And I was lucky enough to listen to the audio (read beautifully by Jahren herself) while I drove past the blazing autumn leaves of New England, so every tree seemed somehow magical. If someone had taught me about plants the way Jahren does, where it is not just a process to learn and a life cycle to memorize, but where every single step along the way is a miracle in and of itself, I can see myself seriously considering Botany as a potential major. This book in the hands of a college student could be life changing.Some may find Jahren's story not interesting enough for a memoir. But this is not a memoir that is built around a journey. It is showing you who she is, and a big part of it focuses on the incredibly close relationship she has with her lab partner, Bill. While they mean absolutely everything to one another, they are not intimate friends, not secret sharers, not confidants. Learning the rhythms of their conversation and the routines of their friendship will show you the kind of relationship you probably haven't seen before. Jahren covers many things here besides science. Parenthood, the chill Scandinavian traditions of the Midwest, the slog of early academic life, and her own struggle with bipolar disorder. Her writing is simple but deliberate and lovely. I enjoyed every moment listening to her read.

My first thoughts, this book is in a word, odd. It is a memoir written by a bipolar paleobiologist and her Asperger‚Äôs like, one-handed best friend/lab assistant. They stumble through the US and Europe trying to do good science. The book is about three things. 1. Science: we learn about the scientific method, how a mass spectrometer works, and that trees have memory (all of which was much more interesting than I would have thought). 2. Love and Family: in all its permutations, good/bad, expressed/unexpressed, chosen/not chosen. 3. Academia: a close and accurate look at the tarnished Ivory tower with tales of sexism, cut throat competition, and the never ending search for money. Despite her struggles, she becomes an award winning and accomplished scholar with her best friend by her side. My final thoughts: this book is in a word, captivating.

What a shame this utterly amazing book has such a lame title. My advice is to forget the title and read the book. Jahren, a three-time Fulbright winner, has written a reader-friendly, relationship-centered sequence of stories about her experience as a paleobotany researcher. There is much to learn and Jahren doesn't shrink from explaining it. However, the terms and structure are highly accessible. The book is one of those rare fusions of science and humanity that many readers so often wish for but can seldom find. The reason is simple--it takes a polymath like Ms. Jahren to understand and love the labwork and yet also be able to explain it to non-scientists. This is the biology class--really much more--you wish you'd experienced. At the same time, Jahren is clear about the difficulties of an academic scientist's life--getting grants, writing proposals, acquiring equipment, paying lab assistants, the necessity of moving on to better opportunities. She writes with joy about marriage, her son, her struggle with bipolarity, and most of all about her talented, brilliant assistant, Bill.About the title: this is apparently the season of "The Girl Who..." after the success of The Girl on the Train. Unfortunately, "Lab GIRL" is diminutive, and diminishes, the complex, warm, fascinating PhD scientist we meet in its pages. I wish the publishers had worked harder to come up with a title that better represents this story.
An uneven read for me. Loved the science-y bits, found the personal memoir sections either tedious or grating.

This is a textbook case of 'it's not you, it's me.' I understand the appeal, and in a lot of ways I'm thrilled about this book's mainstream success (women in STEM fields and healthy, platonic relationships between men and women are two things we need more of in media), but there were only so many loving descriptions of trees I could take after a while. There was just too much science and not enough human interest to keep me engaged, and while I wouldn't say you need to be knowledgeable about biology to approach this book, a certain amount of interest would be helpful, and I just don't have that, at all. And the audiobook was a mistake; the author narrates it with a positively bizarre amount of melodrama (like, actually in tears at multiple points, and I'm sorry if that makes me sound callous but I really don't react well to overly sentimental narration), so I can't say it was a pleasant listening experience... But anyway, really not a bad book, just not my kind of book.
